issues.description: Whether the district court properly granted summary judgment to the Estate on its breach of contract claim against Wood and denied Wood's cross-motion for summary judgment.
issues.key_reasoning: The court found the contract language unambiguous in barring Wood from claiming the Decedent’s pension and annuity benefits, and thus her acceptance of those benefits constituted a breach. The Estate was entitled to summary judgment.

issues.description: Whether the district court correctly determined that the Decedent’s father was an intended third-party beneficiary of the Property Settlement Agreement (PSA), and that the Estate, as assignee, was entitled to damages.
issues.key_reasoning: The court held that New Jersey law does not require the beneficiary to be specifically named, and the PSA’s language and circumstances showed intent to benefit a third party, making the Decedent’s father a third-party beneficiary whose claim could be assigned to the Estate.

issues.description: Whether the district court abused its discretion in awarding pre-judgment interest and declining to toll its accumulation.
issues.key_reasoning: The court found no exceptional circumstances warranting tolling; delays were part of normal litigation and the Estate’s request to reopen discovery was made in good faith and granted by the court.

issues.description: Whether the district court abused its discretion in awarding attorney’s fees and in the calculation of the amount.
issues.key_reasoning: The court found the hourly rate and hours billed reasonable, and the 10% reduction for overbilling was within the district court’s discretion; the unsuccessful claims were related to the successful claim and did not warrant further reduction.

key_precedents: Sheet Metal Workers Int’l Ass’n Loc. Union No. 27, AFL-CIO v. E.P. Donnelly, Inc., 737 F.3d 879 (3d Cir. 2013)
Broadway Maint. Corp. v. Rutgers, 90 N.J. 253 (1982)
N. Bergen Rex Transp., Inc. v. Trailer Leasing Co., 158 N.J. 561 (1999)
Furst v. Einstein Moomjy, Inc., 182 N.J. 1 (2004)
summary_text:
Appeal from the judgment of the United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York (Eric N. Vitaliano, Judge).

UPON DUE CONSIDERATION, IT IS HEREBY ORDERED, ADJUDGED, AND DECREED that the judgment of the district court, entered on July 19, 2023, is AFFIRMED.

Defendant-Counter-Claimant-Appellant Andrae E. Wood (“Wood’) appeals the award of summary judgment in favor of Plaintiff-Counter-Defendant-Appellee Vivienne Culwick, as Administratrix of the Estate of Steven Eliot Wood (the “Estate”), on the Estate’s breach of contract claim, the denial of summary judgment in Wood’s favor on that same claim, and the award of damages against Wood in the sum of $924,818.35, plus post-judgment interest. We assume the parties’ familiarity with the underlying facts, procedural history, and issues on appeal, to which we refer only as necessary to explain our decision to affirm.
